I could not find my changes even on the stash list.

fields.description:
Example, if the user sets up their user Account preferences with Dutch/Nederlads the UI page load times increases 2x or 3x comparing to when the profile has English as profile language .

Workaround is to switch the language back to English, then page loads time goes down.
fields.summary: When Account Settings language is non frequently used languages, UI pages load time increases

fields.description:
There are some common error messages on Pipelines that could be altered to better reflect what to do to resolve the error.

For example, when you have a clone depth issue the error message that shows up is\\
"We hit a glitch and couldn't clone the repository. Please rerun the pipeline.\\
See our documentation"

However, it should show something that would lead to a resolution to the issue, such as "try raising your -depth option on your .yml configuration file".
fields.summary: Improve Pipelines error message when clone fails

fields.description: When I receive an email notification for a commit it contains the author, repository, commit hash + link, and commit msg. It doesn't include the branch the commit was on. If the commit message doesn't give me enough context (e.g. "Removed trailing whitespace"), I have to click through to the commit to find which branch the commit was on. It would be convenient to include the branch, and perhaps a link to the branch, in the email.
fields.summary: Include Branch in Commit Notification Email

fields.description:
Might help save a few CPU cycles and build time.

Basically we have a few builds where only 2 of the 5 steps require the artifacts, would be nice if you could add a flag to disable these.

Source: https://twitter.com/jeroendra/status/1019829831377170432
fields.summary: Ability to prevent a step from downloading artifacts

fields.description:
TL;DR: if you rename a mercurial branch, open pull requests issued to the original name get dysfunctional

How to recreate:

# On a given mercurial repository, create a branch, add a commit, push it to bitbucket
# Open a pull request on that branch
# Rename the branch as follows:

## Create a new branch from the last commit of the existing branch, like "hg branch new_branch"
## Create an 'empty' commit by {{touch}}-ing any of the contained files and commiting, so that the new branch exists
## {{hg update}} to the old branch name
## {{hg commit --close-branch}} to close the old branch
# Push to bitbucket
# Open the existing pull request. Click on {{Edit}} in the top right corner.

What should happen:

* I would like to select the new name here and pull in the ('empty') commits to update the pull request

What actually happens:

* A rotating progress indicator spins on the bottom of the screen.
* I cannot select any originating branch name using the pull-down menu or typing (see attached screenshot)
fields.summary: renaming a branch in mercurial breaks editing open pull requests

Kindly help further.

I tried to do it using branch permissions and refs/tags/... but it doesn't work, is there another way to do it? Or do you guys have plans to develop a tags permissions?

Thank you.

fields.description:
I have a work bitbucket account and a personal bitbucket account. Using [this|http://fredrik.anderzon.se/2017/03/14/setting-up-ssh-keys-for-multiple-bitbucket-github-accounts/] I've setup so that I can work on both accounts from the same computer.

However I'm getting the following error in all repositories that uses npm (package.json):

"Failed to load package.json from Bitbucket. ({"code":"FRAME_SRC_CONSUMER_CALLBACK_MISMATCH","message":"Module URL must start with the OAuth consumer callback URL"})"

I only get this on my personal account which is the one with the custom url and I'm sure that's the cause, I'm just not sure how to solve it.

Any help would be greatly appreciated!

Kristjan
fields.summary: Failed to load package.json from Bitbucket.

fields.description:
I've got a simple pipeline file:

{code}
image: softinstigate/maven-aws

pipelines:
  # For all branches we will verify the code can be built successfully
  default:
    - step:
        name: Verify code
        caches:
          - maven
        script:
          - mvn verify
{code}

During the {{Build setup}} I can see

{code}
Cache "maven": Downloading
Cache "maven": Downloaded 138 MB in 12 seconds
Cache "maven": Extracting
Cache "maven": Extracted in 2 seconds
{code}

But then during my {{Verify code}} step maven starts downloading all dependencies:

{code}
Downloaded from maven2: http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/com/fasterxml/jackson/core/jackson-annotations/maven-metadata.xml (3.3 kB at 34 kB/s)
Downloaded from central: https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/com/fasterxml/jackson/core/jackson-annotations/maven-metadata.xml (3.3 kB at 41 kB/s)
Downloading from maven2: http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/com/fasterxml/jackson/core/jackson-databind/maven-metadata.xml
Downloading from central: https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/com/fasterxml/jackson/core/jackson-databind/maven-metadata.xml
{code}

I'm not running into this problem with my node projects.
fields.summary: Maven dependencies are not being cached in pipeline build

fields.description: Scheduled pipelines have an hour offset in certain timezones which are causing a scheduled build delay.
fields.summary: Scheduled builds are not starting at designated time (BP-2709)

fields.description: When side-by-side diff is clicked, then click close and then click diff side-by-side again, diff does not appear.

fields.description:
PR Mergers can leave smart style commit messages in this format during a PR:

{code}
BUG-1234 #ready-for-qa #comment As the PR Merger comments should attribute to me.
{code}

Unfortunately both the #ready-for-qa action and the #comment action are attributed to the PR creator, not the user performing the PR merge.

Similar to\\
BCLOUD-13960
fields.summary: On a PR Merge, Smart Commit messages during a merge should attribute correctly

fields.description:
When someone in my team replies to a comment I made on a pull request, I get an email notification. When I want to respond to that comment I click the "View this pull request" link in the email. An url in the form of

https://bitbucket.org/my_org/my_project/pull-requests/123/my_pull_request#comment-12345678

is opened. The page loads the overview tab, which takes quite long for a pull request with changes to 200 files. After loading has completed, the app tries to scroll to the comment but does not land correctly. I have to manually ⌘-F in the browser to find the comment I'm looking for.

More details:\\
In my case the {{#page}} element is 148,000px in height. {{window.scrollY}} is at 25,117 event though it should be at 31,152.

If you need further details, let me know. I'm happy to help.
fields.summary: Scrolling to comment does not work for pull requests

fields.description:
My Bitbucket account is now authenticated via SAML. When attempting to add the account in Sourcetree, Sourcetree OFTEN fails to detect the completion of successful auth flow, with the only option available to 'cancel'. Result: I can't add the account to Sourcetree.

Repro:

* Sourcetree 2.7.6 on macOS

# open Sourcetree > preferences > Accounts
# click Add...
# host: Bitbucket; auth type: OAuth; username: "no account connected"

* click 'Connect Account'

# a modal dialog/sheet opens titled "Please sign in to this account:"

* enter email, get redirected to my SAML provider (AzureAD), authenticate
* after successful authentication, the modal dialog presents the default web view (list of repos), with no means to complete the process (ref attached screen shot)
* with no other option, click Cancel

Note that this is not 100% reproducible, it was happening all morning (~6 attempts) but in the very last one where I was creating the above repro steps, it worked - the dialog closed and the account was added.
fields.summary: Sourcetree OFTEN can't connect SAML-based accounts

fields.description: According [to the documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/environment-variables-794502608.html], as well as a printenv output, it seems there's no way to know who kicked off the deployment. fields.description:
This may be a dup of BCLOUD-16368 (not enough info there to say).

If you edit an SSH key in Team settings and save it, the key is moved to the user's settings.

Repro:

# go to https://bitbucket.org/account/user/<team_name>/ssh-keys/  where <team_name> is a team
# edit a key, change the label, hit save
# observe that the edited key is now absent in the key list
# go to https://bitbucket.org/account/user/<user_name>/ssh-keys/ where <user_name> is your user id
# observe the key _is_ listed in the user's key list
fields.summary: Saving SSH keys within Team settings after edit results in moving to user settings

fields.description:
When creating a PR via the REST API for a repo which has default reviewers, if the request does not explicitly specify reviewers for the PR, the default reviewers should be used.

For example:

POST /rest/api/1.0/projects/{projectKey}/repos/{repositorySlug}/pull-requests

{\\
"title": "...",\\
"state": "OPEN",\\
"fromRef": {\\
"id": "refs/heads/source"\\
},\\
"toRef": {\\
"id": "refs/heads/dest"\\
},\\
"locked": false\\
}

Note no reviewers specified in POST body, so default reviewers should be set.
fields.summary: Use default reviewers when creating a PR via REST API

fields.description:
h3. how to reproduce:
* create a PR with a long file changes
* add a comment to 2nd part of content, lets say its a 50 line
* to verify the issue, add also a comment to e.g. 10 line
* move changes from line 50 to another file

h3. what happen:
* there is a "2" comment icon on the top (file list)
* there is only 1 comment displayed on the file preview

h3. how it should work:
* when I add a comment to line 50, then move the code to another file or reverse the changes back, the comment should be displayed e.g. above the file or anywhere but should NOT disappear :)

Im not sure if its bug or feature but its very annoying

fields.description:
As per the recommendation to my question (https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/How-to-manage-pull-request-build-status-with-pipelines-when/qaq-p/840763) raising this bug.

As a code reviewer I want to approve pull request only when a successful full build is completed so that I can be certain only quality code is checked into the main branch.

Result: We have a pipelines build in which the majority of work, including tests, is done in a manually triggered step*. When a check-in occurs the build finishes the first step (which has to be automatic), this marks the build as successful even though subsequent steps have not been attempted. This is problematic when a pull request is started as we also have a branch permission set to require a successful build. The trivial build with only the first step complete satisfies the successful build rule making the rule effectively useless.

Expected Result: The successful build rule is not satisfied until a paused or incomplete build is fully complete.

* This is done for 2 main reasons. 1. We wish to encourage regular check-in but also not use up build minutes. 2. The build uses external limited resources so we also limit concurrent builds by making it a deployment (this is a hack but there is no other way to limit concurrent builds using pipelines).
fields.summary: Incomplete builds should not be marked as successful

fields.description:
At the moment, when a pull request is updated, a list is shown with which commits were added: "Blah UPDATED by adding 13 commits 4 hours ago"

It would be great if a similar list of commits were shown to indicate the commits that existed when the pull request was opened. At the moment we get "Blah OPENED this pull request 8 hours ago" with no commit summary.

We rebase and fixup commits in PRs. Sometimes comments are placed on the commits and not the diff. Those comments are available when the PR is first opened but after an update comments can be lost from the PR history.

Ideally comments shown as commits for the PR would best show up on the activity and track fixups (like Gitlab does) but that's a much harder fix and a separate request to this.
fields.summary: Show commits used when creating the pull request

fields.description: Azure Storage now offers a dedicated container for serving static web pages.  Seeing as how you have an integration to deploy resources to an AWS S3, I would propose that you create on for Azure's Blob Storage, as well.
fields.summary: Example or integration to deploy to Azure Blob Storage

fields.description:
Bitbucket currently doesn't handle Mercurial bookmarks as sources for pull requests, only Mercurial branches. This look to be an attempt to emulate the widely used PR workflow used with git branches. The problem is that HG branches are _NOT_ the equivalent of git branches, rather bookmarks are, this is clearly stated in [https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/Bookmarks](Link URL).

This means our mercurial workflow is borked when using BB, as we rely on bookmarks as opposed to heavy weight branches. This manifests itself as automatic updating of an outstanding pull request to a master repo whenever _any_ bookmark on the same branch is pushed to the source repo. This is not helpful behaviour and continually causes us problems and is near impossible to work around without adding in extra staging repos. And no we aren't going to use mercurial branches, they suck in comparison with bookmarks, we'd go to git first, which we don't want to do.

To get the equivalent workflow for a git repo, pull requests need to be issued against hg bookmarks as well as hg branches. If you did this, you'd be supporting HG at the same level as git.
fields.summary: Have Mercurial Bookmarks Be Sources For Pull Requests

fields.description:
After creating the new tag, it is not getting appeared in the list under commits tab\\
It is able to show if we go to another project and come back to the current project.

Steps:

# Open Commits view.
# Select a particular commit id.
# Create a tag
# Go back to commits view.
# Search for Tags under Branches dropdown.
# The new tag is not getting appeared in the list of tags.
# The same is getting appeared in Source view.

Workaround: Go to another project and come back to current project, tags are getting refreshed in Commits view.
fields.summary: New tag does not always appear in list on commits view

fields.description:
The steps:

# I created pull request from bitbucket from *develop* to *master* branch.

!2899822774-Screen%20Shot%202018-07-11%20at%2012.36.13%20PM.png|thumbnail!

!1121326650-Screen%20Shot%202018-07-11%20at%2012.36.21%20PM.png|thumbnail!

# I see conflict in view, I submit pull request

!1189575815-Screen%20Shot%202018-07-11%20at%2012.37.20%20PM.png|thumbnail!

# I go to CLI, then go to my master branch, do *git merge develop* - conflict is shown also in CLI
# I resolve conflict locally and push changes from CLI - i.e. *git commit -m 'Fix conflict*',  then *git push*
# I open bitbucket with my PR, it shows as merged - but *conflict is still shown there*, although it was resolved (from technical point of view - code is fine, this is just that conflict shouldn't be seen here after resolve).

!3185467837-Screen%20Shot%202018-07-11%20at%2012.38.30%20PM.png|thumbnail!

!3659183676-Screen%20Shot%202018-07-11%20at%2012.38.49%20PM.png|thumbnail!

!1781311806-Screen%20Shot%202018-07-11%20at%2012.39.00%20PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Conflict still shown after successfully resolved and merged from CLI.

fields.description:

Could the paging controls be displayed at the top and bottom of the list of repos?

Thanks,

fields.description:
When creating a Pull Request, BB sets a description based on the commit messages in the PR.

When auto-updating, this is not done (understandably).

Solutions:

# Auto-update the description (not desirable for obvious reasons)
# Include a Button when Updating a PR to automatically populate the description from the PR
# A hybrid approach (using a "macro" embedded in the description or a flag that says that the description should track the commits)
fields.summary: Ability to update pull request description with new commits

There's an extra "c" after ".com"

fields.description:

Otherwise i would need to set an order in the creole-toc.

fields.description: While I was trying to change access on a repository I noticed that bitbucket started showing my name as "Daniel Honig". That person does not appear to be anyone on our teams. The icon show with the name is mine. It appears that somehow my ID and his are overlapped. This looks like it could be a security issue.
fields.summary: User collision - security issue

fields.description:
When viewing a PR as a reviewer, the primary (blue) button is "Merge"; it would be nice if "Approve" was the primary instead to avoid accidental merges. For the author of the PR the primary button should still be "Merge" though.

Also, I'm not sure if this is only because I am an admin, but as an admin who is also a reviewer, the current interface is begging for mistakes ("Need to review code; looks good. Where is the blue button? There it is! Oh crap."). I can see the argument for making the "Merge" button the primary button even for admins, but only if the author doesn't have permission to perform the merge (our team allows everyone to merge, so an admin merging a PR for someone else doesn't come up often).
fields.summary: Default primary button on PR is always merge

fields.description:
Content of *bitbucket-pipelines.yml*:

{code}
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        name: Name of step
        image: 
          name: <aws_account_id>.dkr.ecr.<region>.amazonaws.com/namespace/php:latest
          aws: 
            access-key: $AWS_ACCESS_KEY
            secret-key: $AWS_SECRET_KEY
        services:
          - redis
        script:
          - pwd
          - ls -l */*

definitions:
  services:
    redis:
      image: redis:4.0
{code}

Pipelines AWS user has full permission of READ on all resources on ECR.

!3906363619-download.png|thumbnail!

Result of pipelines:

!2391537900-JHup.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: "Unauthorised for ECR" when using private image hosted on AWS ECR

fields.description:
I cannot delete my Attlassian account. Furthermore, in Bitbucket Account Settings there's a link in 'Update your avatar, full name, email address, and password through your Atlassian account' which cannot be accomplished, since I log-in via gmail. In addition, changing a password makes no sense at all since Google is the credentials authority and it will never allow for third party to change such info.\\
And all this happens when I want to clone a repo. Even Sourcetree asks for email/password to access a remote repo, that is a bitbucket one.\\
Amy solution?\\
Regards,\\
Alexander Christov
fields.summary: Not able to delete Atlassian account

fields.description:
We had put a validation on commit in bitbucket. Setting done from https://bitbucket.org/<team>/<repository>/admin/links.\\
The setting says\\
From\\
JIRA (((?P<linker_value>([\w-]+))-\d+))\\
To\\
https://<our-jira-host>/rest/bitbucket/1.0/issue-details/fragme...\\
(This is not editable however)

This was working till last Friday (July 6th, 2018). From this Monday-today, it is giving us error even if we included JIRA id.

The error says\\
Pushing to https://username:password@bitbucket.org/<team>/<repository>.git\\
To https://bitbucket.org/<team>/<repository>.git\\
! [remote rejected] <branch> -> <branch> (pre-receive hook declined)\\
error: failed to push some refs to 'https://[username:password]@bitbucket.org/<team>/<repository>.git'
fields.summary: Unable to push a commit

Could someone please look into this on priority.

fields.description:
It could fetch some time ago but now it can not. Btw, i can login and download oracle driver via browser with my username/password. Also It works properly on my local machine.

Access denied to: https://maven.oracle.com/com/oracle/jdbc/ojdbc7/12.1.0.2/ojdbc7-12.1.0.2.pom , ReasonPhrase:Forbidden.

It is added in setting.xml at root of project folder.

{code}
#!xml

 <servers>
        <server>
            <id>maven.oracle.com</id>
            <username>{myusername}</username>
            <password>{mypass}</password>
            <configuration>
                <basicAuthScope>
                    <host>ANY</host>
                    <port>ANY</port>
                    <realm>OAM 11g</realm>
                </basicAuthScope>
                <httpConfiguration>
                    <all>
                        <params>
                            <property>
                                <name>http.protocol.allow-circular-redirects</name>
                                <value>%b,true</value>
                            </property>
                        </params>
                    </all>
                </httpConfiguration>
            </configuration>
        </server>
    </servers>
{code}
fields.summary: Can not fetch oracle dependencies

fields.description: It would be nice to have the ability to set chat notification for a team project instead of having to set them for every repo inside this particular project.
fields.summary: Chat notifications for Project

fields.description:
The "Last Updated" sort is useful, but not always what we need because a repo is updated if any change (not commit) is made. Adding more date sorting options to the Dashboard and Repositories listings would make navigating repos much more user friendly. I've been cleaning up space and moving repos around lately and it's been a bit frustrating having to click into the repo to check the last commit.

I would love to see a ["Sort By Date"] column with ["Last Updated", "Last Viewed", "Last Commited", "Created"] options in both the Dashboard and Repositories views. Saving the last viewed filter seems to already work seemlessly.

Related issues (that I could find, before creating a new issue):\\
[#4689]\\
[#11322]\\
[#12251]\\
[#12257]
fields.summary: Add "Last Commit" as sortable option

fields.description: I have started Kotlin development and understand itis a new language, but it is fairly easy to add Kotlin coloring to the code in the WYSIWYG editor. Please implement it!
fields.summary: Please add Kotlin auto code coloring!!!!

fields.summary: Allow ordering of the files in a pull request
Manual trigger for steps running in parallel

fields.description:
We've defined a set of default reviewers in our BitBucket Cloud repository.

However, it seems to have zero effect. Any time we create a PR from a fork, the list of reviewers is always empty and the list of default reviewers does not seem to get applied at all.

This is confusing and frustrating. The pull request is being created in the repository being merged into and not the fork. Why wouldn't default reviewers have an effect?

Adding to the issue I can't add default reviewers to my private fork unless I give access to the fork to all of the reviewers who already have access to the main repository. Effectively each user can only add themselves as a reviewer which is rather silly.

I can however add the users manually every time I create the pull request but the entire point of having default reviewers in the first place is to remove the need for doing this.
fields.summary: Default reviewers does not work on PRs created from forks

fields.description:
Feedback on the upgrade plan payment form - don't clear the entire form because one field was missed out (I'd skipped "state" as I don't live in one) and the error message doesn't provide any clues either. So nearly bailed - how many do I wonder?

Reported via: https://twitter.com/longwhitedig/statuses/1014927428278538240
fields.summary: Feedback on Payment Form

fields.description:
Hi,

we have a pretty standard workflow in Bitbucket using Hg. We have a master repo in bit bucket and everyone working on that project has their own private fork of that repo in bitbucket that they use for work in progress. We typically using mercurial bookmarks to track our work. When some work is complete, a dev issues a pull request to the master repo, that's reviewed and merged/rejected. All good. However, if the dev pushes a second changeset to their private repo before an outstanding pull to the master repo is accepted, that outstanding pull request is automatically updated to include the new changeset. It also does this silently and the dev doing the pull request is not notified.

This is beyond annoying. Is there a way to stop bitbucket pull requests automatically updating for mercurial? If not, could you please put that in as an option we can turn on. This has caused several problems for us.

thanks

Bruno
fields.summary: Stopping Mercurial Pull Requests Automatically Updating to Latest Version

git push origin --mirror

?

Please help\\
Thanks,\\
Abouzied
fields.summary: Restoring remote repo

fields.description:
Heya, I'm fairly new here so first of all, I would like to add some feedback as I'm not sure where to do this properly:

* It's a pain to get here. It's nearly impossible to find the issue tracker, be it via google or any bitbucket websites.
* Clicking in the breadcrumb on 'Public Issue Tracker' will lead me to https://bitbucket.org/account/user/site/projects/PROJ and that doesn't make sense
* Clicking in the breadcrumb on 'Bitbucket' will lead me to https://bitbucket.org/site/ and 'I was never there'.

This doesn't seem to be the intended behavior to me.

My actual bug report is rather simple, it seems like the PHP highlights are not working in pull requests. Whenever I make a pull request and view it (either the PR or the commits, doesn't matter) or when I try to review another pull request, it looks like it has no highlight at all, so I guess it doesn't detect the PHP files? This makes reviewing really annoying.
fields.summary: PHP highlight in diffs seems to be broken

fields.description:
When selecting a branch from which to view source code, if we don't click literally on the text, and instead just on its container (i.e. the span and not the link), the issue can be seen. Although the dropdown selection does update with the new selection, the page doesn't actually update. In the attached gif, it can be seen that commit history is only updating once we click on the text.

!2509408095-ezgif-5-d596bf99ec.gif|thumbnail!
